metadata.title: Design and Analysis of an Extreme-Scale, High-Performance, and Modular Agent- Based Simulation Platform
metadata.description:
Agent-based modeling is indispensable for studying complex systems across many domains. However, existing simulation platforms exhibit two major issues: performance and modularity. Low performance prevents simulations with a large number of agents, increases development time, limits parameter exploration, and raises computing costs. Inflexible software designs motivate modelers to create their own tools, diverting valuable resources.

This dissertation introduces a novel simulation platform called BioDynaMo and its significant improvement, TeraAgent, to alleviate these challenges via three major works.

First, we lay the platform's foundation by defining abstractions, establishing software infrastructure, and implementing a multitude of features for agent-based modeling. We demonstrate BioDynaMo's modularity through use cases in neuroscience, epidemiology, and oncology. We validate these models and show the simplicity of adding new functionality with few lines of code.

Second, we perform a rigorous performance analysis and identify challenges for shared-memory parallelism. Provided solutions include an optimized grid for neighbor searching, mechanisms to reduce the memory access latency, and exploiting domain knowledge to omit unnecessary work. These improvements yield up to three orders of magnitude speedups, enabling simulations of 1.7 billion agents on a single server.

Third, we present TeraAgent, a distributed simulation engine that allows scaling out the computation of one simulation to multiple servers. We identify and address server communication bottlenecks and implement solutions for serialization and delta encoding to accelerate and reduce data transfer. TeraAgent can simulate 500 billion agents and scales to 84096 CPU cores.


BioDynaMo has been widely adopted, including a prize-winning radiotherapy simulation recognized as a top 10 breakthrough in physics in 2024.

data.title: Design and Analysis of an Extreme-Scale, High-Performance, and Modular Agent- Based Simulation Platform

metadata.title: Rapid Acquisition of 103Rh Solid-State NMR Spectra by 31P Detection and Sideband Selective Methods
metadata.description:
Data archived here corresponds to the experimental and simulation data discussed in:
"Rapid Acquisition of 103Rh Solid-State NMR Spectra by 31P Detection and Sideband Selective Methods." This includes experimental datasets from TopSpin, files for SIMPSON simulations, and the output files from the DFT calculations using AMS 2021. Python scripts used in the data analysis are also included

data.title: Rapid Acquisition of 103Rh Solid-State NMR Spectra by 31P Detection and Sideband Selective Methods

metadata.title: Roadmap to fault tolerant quantum computation using topological qubit arrays
metadata.description: This data accompanies the preprint "Roadmap to fault tolerant quantum computation using topological qubit arrays" and contains simulation data used in the figures.

data.title: Roadmap to fault tolerant quantum computation using topological qubit arrays

metadata.title: Baseline Symptom Data of Adult Childhood Cancer Survivors from the St. Jude Lifetime Cohort Study (SJLIFE)
metadata.description: This dataset includes data from 2,000 adult survivors of childhood cancer in the St. Jude Lifetime Cohort Study (SJLIFE). It contains baseline symptom assessments across 10 domains (cardiac, pulmonary, sensation, nausea, movement, pain, memory, fatigue, anxiety, and depression) and self-reported individual characteristics (age, sex, race/ethnicity, education level, personal income, and marital status) at the time of the survey. This dataset was used for real-world data application in the published study, Estimation of Personal Symptom Networks Using the Ising Model for Adult Survivors of Childhood Cancer: A Simulation Study with Real-World Data Application, in Clinical Epidemiology (PMID: 39049900; PMCID: PMC11268787; DOI: 10.2147/CLEP.S464104).

journal.title: Estimation of Personal Symptom Networks Using the Ising Model for Adult Survivors of Childhood Cancer: A Simulation Study with Real-World Data Application

data.title: Baseline Symptom Data of Adult Childhood Cancer Survivors from the St. Jude Lifetime Cohort Study (SJLIFE)

metadata.title: RNA-FRETools/fretraj: 0.2.11
metadata.description:
What's Changed

  • Incorporation of Detection Efficiency in the Burst Simulation of FRETraj by @felixErichson in https://github.com/RNA-FRETools/fretraj/pull/5
  • Use serial ID for attach_id and clarify documentation by @fdsteffen in https://github.com/RNA-FRETools/fretraj/pull/6
  • Switch to setuptools build and remove legacy Github workflows

New Contributors

  • @felixErichson made their first contribution in https://github.com/RNA-FRETools/fretraj/pull/5
  • @fdsteffen made their first contribution in https://github.com/RNA-FRETools/fretraj/pull/6

Full Changelog: https://github.com/RNA-FRETools/fretraj/compare/v0.2.10...0.2.11

metadata.title: Global Simulations Suggest Biomass Burning Aerosols are Regionally Important Ice Nucleating Particles
metadata.description: This repository supplements the research article titled "Global Simulations Suggest Biomass Burning Aerosols are Regionally Important Ice Nucleating Particles" and contains - 1. Postprocessed simulation results from running the UK Met Office Unified Model (UM); the rose suites are stated in the accompanying manuscript, 2. Processed measurement data from the DOE- and NSF-funded campaigns, and 3. Python scripts used to prepare INP plots and analyses presented in the paper.

data.title: Global Simulations Suggest Biomass Burning Aerosols are Regionally Important Ice Nucleating Particles

metadata.title: sim-tools
metadata.description:
Added

  • Add simpy and treat-sim to the environment, as these were required in the notebooks in docs/.
  • Add nbqa and pylint to the environment for linting, plus a relevant files lint.sh and .pylintrc.
  • Add tests for output_analysis functions (functional, unit and back tests).
  • Add validation of parameters in ReplicationsAlgorithm.
  • Add validation of data type in OnlineStatistics.

Changed

  • Simplified distribution value type tests to a single test where possible using pytest.mark.parametrize.
  • Linted .py and .ipynb files using pylint (most addressed, some remain unresolved).
  • Provided advice on tests, building docs and linting in the README.md.
  • 00_front_page.md now just imported README.md (reducing duplication, and keping it up-to-date).

Removed

  • Removed duplicate sw21_tutorial.ipynb.

Fixed

  • Within confidence_interval_method, convert data provided to OnlineStatistics to np.array so that it is actually used to update the class (when before, it was not, as it was a list).
metadata.notes: If you use this software, please cite it using the metadata from this file.

metadata.title: Atomistic Parsers
metadata.description: `atomistic-parsers` is a plugin for the NOMAD software (https://zenodo.org/doi/10.5281/zenodo.8366162) providing parsers for a variety of simulation codes, primarily focused on those supporting classical representations or methods.
metadata.notes: If you use this software, please cite it using the metadata from this file.
